Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 4:00 PM—just one hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers this week.” I scrolled through my call list, rehearsing my pitch, feeling the pressure build in my chest. Then my phone buzzed with a message from the volunteer coordinator: “URGENT—new safety procedures must be implemented immediately. If not, we risk shutting down the food pantry tonight.” I was supposed to help set up after work, but the coordinator’s message made it clear I needed to review the new guidelines now and be ready to act as soon as my shift ended. My hands trembled as I weighed the demands—my job needed my focus, but the pantry needed me to step up. I stared at my headset, torn between dialing the next number and opening the coordinator’s email, my mind racing with the fear of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
